Best Answer - Chosen by Voters Can I just start by saying that TGI Fridays and Olive Garden are NOT fancy restaurants? They are mid-level dining, at best. TGI Fridays and Olive Garden are cheap chain restaurants. No rich person eats at those places, I'm just keeping it real girl. Those are kind of cheap seated-dining restaurants. Think about it. An average meal at McDonalds is like 7 dollars after tax, and an average meal at TGI Fridays is like 14 bucks after tax. Fourteen dollars really isn't a lot to pay for a meal. Rich restaurants are charging at least 25/30 dollars a plate. And I have worked in a mid-level dining restaurant before, and VERY FEW people there where White, I'm just being honest. I worked at a Ruby Tuesday as a bartender, and all of the cooks were Hispanic or Black, the food-runners were Hispanic, the servers were African (from Africa) and Middle Eastern and Black and there was a couple White girls but they were from overseas somewhere like Ukraine. I worked at a local mid-level dining restaurant too, and it was the same situation almost to a tee. The ONLY White people I ever encountered in either restaurant was the customers and the managers. Seriously.
I'll let you know what the"difference"is, though. The difference is that in fast food restaurants, the workers don't actually have to ever really hold an in-depth conversation with the customers. The customers ask for a #1, and the workers know what to do. In a sit-down restaurant like TGI Fridays, the workers have to talk to the customers in-depth. They have to explain things and they also have to be charming. Fast food workers aren't trying to earn tips so they don't need to be able to speak English well. They also aren't considered as true representatives of the company the way waiters and waitresses are.
The reason why you see non-Whites in fast food jobs is because they don't pay enough. So unless the person is under 18, it's unlikely they would get a fast food job when they could just get a waitressing job and actually pay the bills / tuition. A lot of White people are not underprivileged so they don't have to take fast food jobs. Some are, so they do. But anyway, it also really probably depends on where you live. I live in a major metro area, and most TGI Fridays and Olive Garden workers I see are Hispanic or Black, with some Whites mixed in. The majority in my area is non-White, though. 2 years ago Report Abuse 33% 2 Votes 3 people rated this as good
